Otherwise, the standard issues with academic institutions: disconnected departments independently vying for university resources; administration trying to preserve or grow university resources; tension between the two.

You get used to it after a while, though - Lack of diversity in the area wears on staff, faculty and students of color - I wouldn’t recommends staying here long term if you’re a young adult interested in more nightlife options - No tuition reimbursement if you want to get a degree for yourself

review_title: Review - Bucknell University Student Calling Program
job_title: Student Development Manager in Lewisburg, PA
pros: SCP is the best employment opportunity on Bucknell's campus. It has been one of the most rewarding and instructive experiences throughout my college career that I strongly believe has prepared me well for the post-graduate world. The ability to cold-call, develop cases, and network are skills difficult to come by, and building them early will serve you throughout your professional career.
cons: None - the management is great, there is a reward system within the calling room that motivates you to perform well and build confidence, and its the highest paying job on campus.

pros: The hours are flexible and work with schooling
cons: The pay isn't exactly stellar

pros: It obviously depends on who you work for, but for the most part the University is clearly devoted to student learning. This can be good and bad. From the student perspective, it is good because professors have patience and are willing to teach and train you, making it easier to find a job after graduation, though at the cost of pumping out publications like at other major institutions.
cons: Professors value their research just as much as the lectures they teach and the students they teach to. Again, this can be seen as a pro or a con depending on your goals. There are a handful of students whose names end up on publications, but it is by no means a guarantee. Also, most research positions are not paid like at other institutions - though the hands on experience more than makes up for that.

pros:
- Benefits are great.  23 vacation days, 12+ paid holidays, no sick day tracking.  Medical and Dental coverage are good.  10% retirement contributions
- Campus is beautiful
- Great relationships within departments
- Location (if you don't mind rural settings).  Can get to NYC, Baltimore, D.C, Philly, etc within 3-4 hours.
cons:
- Some Faculty do not respect Staff.  They feel that since they have a PhD at the end of their title that they know all and can treat people however they wish
- Student's are snobby and dependent.  They have no problem having mommy or daddy call when they have a problem.
- Location isn't great if you like an urban setting

pros: Great place to work with great people. Beautiful campus and some of the kindest bosses I've ever had. Always something to enjoy on the campus
cons: Pretty secluded from major cities so it might get a bit too quiet. Student life and activities geared only towards students are the main focuses on campus, hence a bit hard to find entertainment outside of the college activities. But they are diverse activities and several cultural events so it's not that much of a hardship

review_title: Great employer, could use some organization
pros: Everyone in the office of admissions is very nice. I look forward to going to work each day. As a student, the full time staff are very supportive and appreciative of the work we do.
cons: Often get conflicting assignments/advice from counselors. Very little notice about meetings. Not very much transparency about the process, just the information they want us to tell perspective students which sometimes makes our answers seem fake.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Lewisburg, PA
pros: Lewisburg is a delightful little town and Bucknell has talented and thoughtful faculty members.
cons: If you're local, Bucknell might be your best option. However, if you're considering a big move to get to Bucknell, look elsewhere. Bucknell's senior administrators are ready to throw faculty under the bus if it will help them to preserve endowment resources. Junior faculty members are made to shoulder a heavy service load and are then subjected to arbitrary and capricious authority.

pros: Great environment, culture and people. Above average work life balance and benefits. Ready to help you learn on the job and support you.
cons: Not really any business mentorship opportunities, undertakes underdeveloped ideas as projects  which causes longer completion time, large amount of outside programs that take you away from work that needs to get done.

job_title: French Teaching Assistant in Austin, TX
pros:
-Great access to Professors

-A great way to give back knowledge you've gained
cons:

-Sometimes students can be difficult and unwilling to learn/participate 
-Time Management is key
-Sometimes Professor can be particular or demanding in instruction style/content

review_title: Wonderful setting, great minds, employees treated like family.

pros: Tuition remission / exchange, two weeks paid time off at winter holidays, unlimited use of the library and athletic facilities
cons: Ineffective lower management in certain departmets. Supervisors look the other way. Watch your back.

review_title: Fun place to work at, fun people to work with

cons: Location: Lewisburg isn't exactly the most busy of places, and is far from any city. The students party a little too much and too often, making it difficult sometimes.

review_title: Great small community with Central PA challenges

review_title: Great to work as a student here
job_title: Campus Tour Guide in Lewisburg, PA

cons: Pay isn't great depending on job: Tour guides don't get paid very much, whereas executive interns and research assistants get paid more.

review_title: Comprehensive learning experience in the world of student affairs.
pros: Beautiful campus, dedicated faculty and staff, and unique student populations made my internships here a worthwhile experience.
cons: As with most small, private, elite universities the campus culture focuses on maintaining it's conservative, traditional identity which presents some serious challenges for student affairs practitioners.

pros: Lifeguards had long breaks, especially with just two guards on duty. The atmosphere was nice.
cons: Getting paid minimum wage after spending hundreds of dollars to gain certification just doesn't seem right. Neighboring pools start at $8 and go up through tenure. Bucknell's rates never went up.
